elements.content: Two ditopic uranyl salophen receptors with benzo-15-crown-5 and benzo-18-crown-6 units (R 1 and R 2 , respectively) have been synthesized from commercially available starting materials. Comprehensive studies on the solid-state ion pair complexation with various alkali and ammonium halides have been conducted. From the 19 obtained solid-state structures (6 structures with R 1 , 13 structures with R 2 ), three general interaction motifs I–III have been observed. Interaction motif I has a separated ion pair with the cation coordinated to the crown ether unit, and the anion or oxygen containing solvent molecule coordinated to the uranyl center. The interaction motif II manifests a polymeric structure with a contact ion pair between the uranyl-coordinated anion and cation coordinated in the crown ether in the adjacent receptor. Interaction motif III consists of a more general stacked packing structure of the receptors with or without ion pairs. From the obtained solid-state structures, the complex R 2 ·NaI shows an interesting formation of infinite coordination polymeric structure where the crown ether complexed sodium cations and the OUO units of the adjacent receptors form a nearly linear 1-D chains. In the course of this work also the first solid-state structure of uranyl salophen acetate complex was obtained (R 2 ·KAcO).

From the obtained solid-state structures, the complex R  2  ⋅NaI shows an interesting formation of infinite coordination polymeric structure where the crown ether complexed sodium cations and the OUO units of the adjacent receptors form a nearly linear 1-D chains. elements.content: Comprehensive solid-state studies of ditopic benzo-15-crown-5 (R 1 ) and benzo-18-crown-6 (R 2 ) based uranyl salophen receptors have revealed three general interaction motifs with various alkali and ammonium halides. The first solid-state complex of uranyl salophens with acetate is presented, and the structure R 2 ·NaI has revealed an interesting solid-state structure consisting of nearly linear O···Na+···OUO chains.
elements.clean_text: Comprehensive solid-state studies of ditopic benzo-15-crown-5 (R  1 ) and benzo-18-crown-6 (R  2 ) based uranyl salophen receptors have revealed three general interaction motifs with various alkali and ammonium halides. The first solid-state complex of uranyl salophens with acetate is presented, and the structure R  2  ⋅NaI has revealed an interesting solid-state structure consisting of nearly linear O⋅⋅⋅Na+⋅⋅⋅OUO chains.

elements.content: In recent years there has been an increasing number of research groups attracted to recognition studies of ion pairs in the solid-state, solution, and gas phase. Ditopic receptors, i.e., molecules having binding site for both cationic and anionic species, have to be designed to overcome more challenges than just simple cation and anion receptors. This is due to the more complicated nature of the ion pairs, and the possible multiple binding stoichiometries involved in ion pair recognition processes. To address these problems, ditopic receptors generally demand more complicated chemical structures, thus leading to demanding synthesis of the receptors. In spite of these challenges, a lot of progress has been made in recent years in the development of ditopic receptors, not only because of the interesting recognition processes themselves, but also due to their multitude of application possibilities in extraction, salt solubilization, sensing, catalysis, and ion transport.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In recent years there has been an increasing number of research groups attracted to recognition studies of ion pairs in the solid-state, solution, and gas phase. Ditopic receptors, i.e., molecules having binding site for both cationic and anionic species, have to be designed to overcome more challenges than just simple cation and anion receptors. This is due to the more complicated nature of the ion pairs, and the possible multiple binding stoichiometries involved in ion pair recognition processes. To address these problems, ditopic receptors generally demand more complicated chemical structures, thus leading to demanding synthesis of the receptors. In spite of these challenges, a lot of progress has been made in recent years in the development of ditopic receptors, not only because of the interesting recognition processes themselves, but also due to their multitude of application possibilities in extraction, salt solubilization, sensing, catalysis, and ion transport.

elements.content: Ditopic receptors are generally built using well-known recognition units for cations and anions. Crown ethers have been extensively studied as a cation recognition unit in various receptors and applications, due to their size variation, and subsequent strong affinity toward cations. Uranyl salophens have attracted a lot of attention as anion and ion pair receptors in the solid-state and solution. The anion recognition properties result from the strong Lewis acid nature of the uranyl cation (UO2 2+). By using a salophen or salen scaffold (N2O2 2–), the seventh coordination site in the equatorial plane of the uranyl group can be coordinated to strongly Lewis basic atoms in anions or in neutral molecules. The uranyl salophens have been utilized as ditopic receptor for alkyl ammonium halides, alkali halides, or chiral ammonium salts. This has been achieved by attaching aromatic side arms to the salophen scaffold to create additional interaction sites, which enable the cation recognition via cation−π interactions simultaneously with the uranyl bound anions. The salophen scaffold has been modified also with sugar groups to create water-soluble uranyl salophen receptors for anions, especially fluoride, in water. Usage of uranyl salophen receptors as integral parts of micellar structures have been studied to allow anion recognition in water.
elements.clean_text: Ditopic receptors are generally built using well-known recognition units for cations and anions. Crown ethers have been extensively studied as a cation recognition unit in various receptors and applications, due to their size variation, and subsequent strong affinity toward cations. Uranyl salophens have attracted a lot of attention as anion and ion pair receptors in the solid-state and solution. The anion recognition properties result from the strong Lewis acid nature of the uranyl cation (UO2 2+). By using a salophen or salen scaffold (N2O2 2-), the seventh coordination site in the equatorial plane of the uranyl group can be coordinated to strongly Lewis basic atoms in anions or in neutral molecules. The uranyl salophens have been utilized as ditopic receptor for alkyl ammonium halides, alkali halides, or chiral ammonium salts. This has been achieved by attaching aromatic side arms to the salophen scaffold to create additional interaction sites, which enable the cation recognition via cation-π interactions simultaneously with the uranyl bound anions. The salophen scaffold has been modified also with sugar groups to create water-soluble uranyl salophen receptors for anions, especially fluoride, in water. Usage of uranyl salophen receptors as integral parts of micellar structures have been studied to allow anion recognition in water.

elements.content: In addition to their use as anion or ditopic receptors, uranyl salophens have also been studied in catalytic applications, for example, in catalysis of Michael addition and Diels–Alder reactions. The catalytic effect is due to neutral ligand coordination to the uranyl center, and the weak van der Waals interactions between the substrate and uranyl salophen receptor have been shown to be a driving force in the catalytic process.

The catalytic effect is due to neutral ligand coordination to the uranyl center, and the weak van der Waals interactions between the substrate and uranyl salophen receptor have been shown to be a driving force in the catalytic process.

elements.content: Recent attention has been directed to the possibility of utilizing the characteristics of actinides, and especially uranium, in developing single-molecule magnets (SMMs) or single-chain magnets (SCMs). Especially, the work of Mazzanti and co-workers has reported the use of pentavalent uranyl cations in SMM and SCM structures, in combination with alkali or transition metals.

Especially, the work of Mazzanti and co-workers has reported the use of pentavalent uranyl cations in SMM and SCM structures, in combination with alkali or transition metals.

elements.content: These structures consist of cation–cation interactions (CCIs), i.e., interactions formed by the actinide dioxo cations acting as a Lewis basic ligand to another metal cation. These interactions are more commonly observed in a pentavalent UO2 + cation than with a hexavalent UO2 2+ dication, due to the stronger Lewis basic character of UO2 +. Because of its stability, there are only a few examples of functionalization of the hexavalent UO2 2+ cation.
elements.clean_text: These structures consist of cation-cation interactions (CCIs), i.e., interactions formed by the actinide dioxo cations acting as a Lewis basic ligand to another metal cation. These interactions are more commonly observed in a pentavalent UO2 + cation than with a hexavalent UO2 2+ dication, due to the stronger Lewis basic character of UO2 +. Because of its stability, there are only a few examples of functionalization of the hexavalent UO2 2+ cation.

elements.content: Our recent work on ditopic crown ethers containing a bis-urea receptor has been a starting point in the utilization of 1,2-diaminobenzocrown ethers in building ditopic ion pair receptors. To probe the usefulness of this type of structural unit in other receptor systems, we envisaged that combining it with an uranyl salophen scaffold would lead to a promising anion recognition site. Although the use of crown ethers in combination with salophen scaffold in ditopic receptors is not entirely new, there exists no solid-state structural and complexation studies with crown ether uranyl salophen receptors. Therefore, in this work we have studied in depth the ion pair complexation behavior of two ditopic crown ether uranyl salophen receptors in the solid-state with alkali or ammonium halides, and present three solid-state interaction motifs observed in the structures. Some of the structures are discussed in more detail as examples, and general observations on the effect of the complexed cation/anion on the interaction motifs will be discussed. Also, the first solid-state structure of acetate bound to uranyl salophen with potassium as the countercation is presented.

To probe the usefulness of this type of structural unit in other receptor systems, we envisaged that combining it with an uranyl salophen scaffold would lead to a promising anion recognition site. Although the use of crown ethers in combination with salophen scaffold in ditopic receptors is not entirely new, there exists no solid-state structural and complexation studies with crown ether uranyl salophen receptors. Therefore, in this work we have studied in depth the ion pair complexation behavior of two ditopic crown ether uranyl salophen receptors in the solid-state with alkali or ammonium halides, and present three solid-state interaction motifs observed in the structures. Some of the structures are discussed in more detail as examples, and general observations on the effect of the complexed cation/anion on the interaction motifs will be discussed. Also, the first solid-state structure of acetate bound to uranyl salophen with potassium as the countercation is presented.

elements.content: Receptors R 1 and R 2 were prepared in three step synthesis starting from commercial benzo-15-crown-5 (1) and benzo-18-crown-6 (2) compounds (). The compounds were nitrated (3, 4) and then reduced (5, 6) in methods described previously. Receptors R 1 and R 2 were obtained by Schiff-base condensation reaction between diamine compounds 5 and 6, and salicylaldehyde (7) in degassed ethanol at 50 °C under argon atmosphere. Consecutive complexation with uranyl acetate dihydrate (8) resulted in immediate solution color change from yellow to red indicating complexation of the Schiff base with the uranyl cation. The products precipitated from the reaction mixture, and the filtered solids were washed with cold ethanol and diethyl ether, and dried in air. The yields of spectroscopically homogeneous solids of R 1 and R 2 were 55–62%. The products were used in the crystallization studies without further purification. The obtained products were analyzed with 1H NMR, 13C NMR, HR-MS, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction (see Figures S1–S7).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Characterization

Receptors R  1  and R  2  were prepared in three step synthesis starting from commercial benzo-15-crown-5 (1) and benzo-18-crown-6 (2) compounds (). The compounds were nitrated (3, 4) and then reduced (5, 6) in methods described previously. Receptors R  1  and R  2  were obtained by Schiff-base condensation reaction between diamine compounds 5 and 6, and salicylaldehyde (7) in degassed ethanol at 50 °C under argon atmosphere. Consecutive complexation with uranyl acetate dihydrate (8) resulted in immediate solution color change from yellow to red indicating complexation of the Schiff base with the uranyl cation. The products precipitated from the reaction mixture, and the filtered solids were washed with cold ethanol and diethyl ether, and dried in air. The yields of spectroscopically homogeneous solids of R  1  and R  2  were 55-62%. The products were used in the crystallization studies without further purification. The obtained products were analyzed with 1H NMR, 13C NMR, HR-MS, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction (see Figures S1-S7).

elements.content: There are a large number of published solid-state structures of uranyl salen or salophen receptors. A CSD search with uranyl salophen and salen scaffolds gives back 92 solid-state structures. In the structures, the fifth equatorial position of the uranyl center is always filled by a hard Lewis basic atom, oxygen or nitrogen atom in a solvent molecule or in adjacent receptor, or an anion (fluoride, chloride, bromide, or phosphate). This is also observed in all of the obtained structures with receptors R 1 and R 2 . The average distance of U···O bonds in the fifth equatorial position is 2.429 Å (52 structures, 9 complexes having pentavalent uranium excluded), and all the shortest U···O distances are found in complexes where the oxygen is in anionic form (2.2320 Å, deprotonated receptor, OGOKIF; 2.2400 Å, hydroxide, HENWIH; 2.2640 Å, pyrenolate, PEXPOZ; 2.2760 Å, phosphate, PIYCOP; 2.2980 Å, phosphate, PIYCEF). When the solid-state structures of uranyl salophen receptors with nitrogen containing solvent molecules are examined, the average U···N distance is found to be 2.604 Å, analyzed from 12 structures. This distance is remarkably longer than the average U···O distance, and it correlates with the Lewis basicity of the atoms. In CSD there are only three solid-state structures of uranyl salophen receptors with coordinated fluoride anion (2.167 Å, EWOLUY; 2.223 Å, XELZAG; 2.209 Å, YALRAF). The U···F distances are remarkably shorter than the average U···O distance, although the U···F distances in the three complexes are only slightly shorter than the shortest U···O distances with anionic O atoms. In CSD there are 12 structures with coordinated chloride, all of them uranyl salophens, and the average U···Cl distance of the structures is 2.730 Å, with distances ranging from 2.705 to 2.781 Å. Only one uranyl salophen structure with uranyl-coordinated bromide is available, having U···Br distance 2.902 Å (HEYXEP).
elements.clean_text:
Solid-State Structures

There are a large number of published solid-state structures of uranyl salen or salophen receptors. A CSD search with uranyl salophen and salen scaffolds gives back 92 solid-state structures. In the structures, the fifth equatorial position of the uranyl center is always filled by a hard Lewis basic atom, oxygen or nitrogen atom in a solvent molecule or in adjacent receptor, or an anion (fluoride, chloride, bromide, or phosphate). This is also observed in all of the obtained structures with receptors R  1  and R  2 . The average distance of U⋅⋅⋅O bonds in the fifth equatorial position is 2.429 Å (52 structures, 9 complexes having pentavalent uranium excluded), and all the shortest U⋅⋅⋅O distances are found in complexes where the oxygen is in anionic form (2.2320 Å, deprotonated receptor, OGOKIF; 2.2400 Å, hydroxide, HENWIH; 2.2640 Å, pyrenolate, PEXPOZ; 2.2760 Å, phosphate, PIYCOP; 2.2980 Å, phosphate, PIYCEF). When the solid-state structures of uranyl salophen receptors with nitrogen containing solvent molecules are examined, the average U⋅⋅⋅N distance is found to be 2.604 Å, analyzed from 12 structures. This distance is remarkably longer than the average U⋅⋅⋅O distance, and it correlates with the Lewis basicity of the atoms. In CSD there are only three solid-state structures of uranyl salophen receptors with coordinated fluoride anion (2.167 Å, EWOLUY; 2.223 Å, XELZAG; 2.209 Å, YALRAF). The U⋅⋅⋅F distances are remarkably shorter than the average U⋅⋅⋅O distance, although the U⋅⋅⋅F distances in the three complexes are only slightly shorter than the shortest U⋅⋅⋅O distances with anionic O atoms. In CSD there are 12 structures with coordinated chloride, all of them uranyl salophens, and the average U⋅⋅⋅Cl distance of the structures is 2.730 Å, with distances ranging from 2.705 to 2.781 Å. Only one uranyl salophen structure with uranyl-coordinated bromide is available, having U⋅⋅⋅Br distance 2.902 Å (HEYXEP).

elements.content: In all the obtained ion pair complexes of R 1 and R 2 containing fluoride or chloride, the anion is coordinated in the fifth equatorial position of the uranyl cation. Bromide is not unambiguous in its coordination behavior with the uranium center since in the obtained structures bromide is either coordinated to the uranyl cation or it is residing elsewhere in the crystal lattice. Bromide can be thus thought as a watershed halide as it is barely Lewis basic enough to coordinate to the uranyl cation. In addition, the two structures obtained with NaI and KI do not have the iodide coordinated to the uranyl center, which is not surprising considering the observations with bromide-containing structures. In all the structures without anions or if the anion is a soft Lewis base, the seventh coordination position is occupied by an oxygen-containing solvate molecule. All the U···Z distances (Z = O, F–, Cl–, or Br–) in the solid-state structures obtained throughout this work are presented in . The U···Z distances presented in are in fairly close agreement with the average U···Z distances from the previously published structures. Some of the deviating U···Z distances in , for example, in structures R 2 ·H 2 O, R 2 ·NaI, R 2 ·NaF, and R 1 ·LiCl, can be explained by hydrogen bonding interactions formed between the uranyl-coordinated anion or solvent molecule with other solvent molecules or anions in the crystal lattice. These interactions are responsible for weakening the coordinative bond between the uranyl cation and the solvent/anion. However, elongation of the U···Z distance is not observed in solid-state structures having a contact ion pair (interaction motif II, ), or when the coordinated anion/solvent does not form other weak interactions. The fairly long U···O distance observed in the R 2 ·KAcO complex compared to the other U···O complexes with an anionic oxygen atom coordinated to the uranyl cation can be explained by the hydrogen bonding between the acetate anion and the two methanol solvate molecules (b and Figure S20).

elements.content: General interaction motifs observed in the solid-state structures of R 1 and R 2 : I, separated ion pair; II, contact ion pair; IIIa, stacked packing of the receptors with solvent molecules; IIIb, stacked packing with contact ion pair (R 1 ·NaBr); IIIc, stacked packing with separated ion pair (R 2 ·NaF). The general schemes are presented only for R 2 although similar interaction motifs are observed also with R 1 . M+ = alkali or ammonium cation, X– = halide or acetate anion, Sol = solvent molecule.
elements.clean_text: 1  General interaction motifs observed in the solid-state structures of R  1  and R  2 : I, separated ion pair; II, contact ion pair; IIIa, stacked packing of the receptors with solvent molecules; IIIb, stacked packing with contact ion pair (R  1 ⋅NaBr); IIIc, stacked packing with separated ion pair (R  2 ⋅NaF). The general schemes are presented only for R  2  although similar interaction motifs are observed also with R  1 . M+ = alkali or ammonium cation, X- = halide or acetate anion, Sol = solvent molecule.

The solid-state structures of R 1 and R 2 have revealed three general interaction motifs (). The interaction motifs I and II are defined as having a separate or contact ion pair in the structure, respectively, and the interaction motif III is defined as stacked packing of the receptor molecules (with or without ion pair). In interaction motif I the ion pair is separated, with anion bound in the uranyl center (Ia), or located away from the receptor, and a solvent molecule coordinated to the uranyl center (Ib). In interaction motif I the receptors form a dimer or polymeric structure with dimeric subunits, through cation···O interactions () between the crown-ether-coordinated cation and a uranyl oxygen. Interaction motif II is defined as having a contact ion pair between the uranyl coordinated anion and the alkali metal cation complexed in the crown ether in the adjacent receptor. Further coordinative bond to the alkali metal cation is formed with salophen oxygen of the adjacent receptor (). The interaction motif III is defined as stacked packing of the receptor molecules, with or without the ion pairs present in the structure (). In the following parts, the interaction motifs are discussed in more detail through presentation of selected examples. Atom labeling and selected bond lengths of all the structures can be found in the SI (see Figures S8–S26).
elements.clean_text:
General Solid-State Interaction Motifs

The solid-state structures of R  1  and R  2  have revealed three general interaction motifs (). The interaction motifs I and II are defined as having a separate or contact ion pair in the structure, respectively, and the interaction motif III is defined as stacked packing of the receptor molecules (with or without ion pair). In interaction motif I the ion pair is separated, with anion bound in the uranyl center (Ia), or located away from the receptor, and a solvent molecule coordinated to the uranyl center (Ib). In interaction motif I the receptors form a dimer or polymeric structure with dimeric subunits, through cation⋅⋅⋅O interactions () between the crown-ether-coordinated cation and a uranyl oxygen. Interaction motif II is defined as having a contact ion pair between the uranyl coordinated anion and the alkali metal cation complexed in the crown ether in the adjacent receptor. Further coordinative bond to the alkali metal cation is formed with salophen oxygen of the adjacent receptor (). The interaction motif III is defined as stacked packing of the receptor molecules, with or without the ion pairs present in the structure (). In the following parts, the interaction motifs are discussed in more detail through presentation of selected examples. Atom labeling and selected bond lengths of all the structures can be found in the SI (see Figures S8-S26).

elements.content: The solid-state complex of R 1 with LiCl crystallized by slow evaporation of acetonitrile solution of R 1 with excess LiCl added in water. The complex crystallized in the monoclinic space group I2/a, with one molecule of R 1 and 1 equiv of LiCl in the asymmetric unit, and with a large number of water solvate molecules forming an extensive hydrogen bonding network ( and Figure S10). The complex R 1 ·LiCl has the interaction motif Ia, a separated ion pair, with the lithium cation bound in the crown ether unit, and the chloride anion coordinated in the uranyl center. The lithium cation is located in the middle of the crown ether unit, with Li···O­(crown ether) distances ranging between 2.104 and 2.362 Å. The coordination sphere of Li+ is filled by a water molecule (d(Li···O) = 2.052 Å) and uranyl oxygen of the adjacent R 1 molecule (d(Li···O) = 2.184 Å). This results in the dimerization of two R 1 ·LiCl complexes, with water molecules “capping” the lithium cations, and preventing further polymeric stacking of R 1 ·LiCl complexes. The chloride anion is coordinated in the fifth equatorial coordination site of the uranyl center with U···Cl– distance 2.806 Å. The chloride anion is further hydrogen bonded with two water molecules, which can explain the slightly longer U···Cl– distance compared to the average U···Cl– distance (2.730 Å), and the U···Cl– distances observed in chloride complexes with R 2 ().
elements.clean_text:
Interaction Motif I

R1⋅LiCl

The solid-state complex of R  1  with LiCl crystallized by slow evaporation of acetonitrile solution of R  1  with excess LiCl added in water. The complex crystallized in the monoclinic space group I2/a, with one molecule of R  1  and 1 equiv of LiCl in the asymmetric unit, and with a large number of water solvate molecules forming an extensive hydrogen bonding network ( and Figure S10). The complex R  1  ⋅LiCl has the interaction motif Ia, a separated ion pair, with the lithium cation bound in the crown ether unit, and the chloride anion coordinated in the uranyl center. The lithium cation is located in the middle of the crown ether unit, with Li⋅⋅⋅O(crown ether) distances ranging between 2.104 and 2.362 Å. The coordination sphere of Li+ is filled by a water molecule (d(Li⋅⋅⋅O) = 2.052 Å) and uranyl oxygen of the adjacent R  1  molecule (d(Li⋅⋅⋅O) = 2.184 Å). This results in the dimerization of two R  1  ⋅LiCl complexes, with water molecules "capping" the lithium cations, and preventing further polymeric stacking of R  1  ⋅LiCl complexes. The chloride anion is coordinated in the fifth equatorial coordination site of the uranyl center with U⋅⋅⋅Cl- distance 2.806 Å. The chloride anion is further hydrogen bonded with two water molecules, which can explain the slightly longer U⋅⋅⋅Cl- distance compared to the average U⋅⋅⋅Cl- distance (2.730 Å), and the U⋅⋅⋅Cl- distances observed in chloride complexes with R  2  ().

elements.content: Similar “capped” dimers were also observed in the solid-state complex R 1 ·KI (Figure S22). In the structure, the potassium cations are capped by water and acetonitrile solvate molecules, and the iodide anions are located in the cavities formed by the packing of the receptors. Water molecules are coordinated in the uranyl cations, and they form hydrogen bonds to the adjacent dimer.

[Unit cell parameters: monoclinic, a = 16.9290(3) Å, b = 18.4658(3) Å, c = 23.7388(5) Å, β = 101.620(2)°.]

elements.content: Complex R 2 ·KAcO crystallized by slow evaporation of methanol solution of R 2 with an excessive amount of KAcO added in water. The complex crystallized in monoclinic space group P21/n, having one R 2 molecule and 1 equiv of KAcO in the asymmetric unit (interaction motif Ia). The potassium cation is located in the middle of the crown ether ring with K+···O­(crown ether) distances ranging between 2.690 and 2.900 Å. Dimeric assembly is formed through symmetric K+···OUO coordination with bond distance 2.678 Å (a and Figure S23). The eighth coordination position of potassium is filled by a crown ether oxygen atom of the adjacent dimeric complex (2.787 Å; b). This coordination results in 1-dimensional coordination polymer along the crystallographic a-axis. This type of packing brings the potassium cations in the adjacent dimers into close vicinity to one another, with the K+···K+ distance being 4.139 Å. Isostructural solid-state complexes were obtained with KCl and KBr (Figures S20 and S21), having very similar unit cell parameters, and similar 1D coordination polymer along the crystallographic a-axis. R 2 ·KAcO is the first solid-state structure of uranyl salophens with acetate anion. The anion is coordinated to the uranyl center with bond length 2.356 Å, and is further hydrogen bonded with methanol solvate molecules (b and Figure S23a), which might explain the slightly longer U···O– distance than expected for U···O– distance from previously published structures.

elements.content: X-ray quality crystals of the complex R 2 ·NaI were obtained by slow diffusion of diethyl ether into acetonitrile solution of R 2 with NaI added in excess in water. The obtained structure has modified binding motif Ib, differing from the previously presented structures by having infinite coordination polymers through O···Na+···OUO coordination along the crystallographic a-axis ().

R2⋅NaI

X-ray quality crystals of the complex R  2  ⋅NaI were obtained by slow diffusion of diethyl ether into acetonitrile solution of R  2  with NaI added in excess in water. The obtained structure has modified binding motif Ib, differing from the previously presented structures by having infinite coordination polymers through O⋅⋅⋅Na+⋅⋅⋅OUO coordination along the crystallographic a-axis ().

elements.content: The sodium cation is located in the center of the crown ether, with Na+···O­(crown ether) distances ranging from 2.417 to 2.595 Å. As an exception to the structures presented above, only five of the crown ether oxygens are coordinated to the sodium cation. The sixth oxygen has fairly long distance to the cation (3.401 Å), and it is hydrogen bonded with a water molecule coordinated to uranyl center in the adjacent molecule (Figure S18). The repeating O···Na+···OUO unit has a total length of 8.203 Å, with individual distances of each bond being 2.306 Å (O···Na+), 2.361 Å (Na+···O), 1.795 Å (OU), and 1.785 Å (UO). The angles of the repeating units in the polymer range from 169.1° to 175.9° (b). In the R 2 ·NaI structure a water molecule is coordinated to the uranyl center with bond length 2.476 Å, which is slightly longer than the average U···O distance (2.426 Å). This is explainable by the hydrogen bonding interactions of the uranyl-coordinated water molecule with the iodide anion (3.407 Å), and the crown ether oxygen in the adjacent complex (2.871 Å).

elements.content: There are only a few examples of uranyl salophen or salen complexes forming OUO···M+ (M = metal) coordination polymers in the solid-state. These structures have pentavalent uranyl coordinated to the metal cation through CCI, and the salen or salophen scaffold has been shown to have a strong stabilizing effect on the highly labile pentavalent uranyl cation. Also, a solid-state complex with pentavalent uranium coordinated to crown-ether-complexed potassium cation has been obtained. In this case the crown ether complexation of the potassium cation disrupts the polymer formation. Obtained structures with interaction motif I present the potential for crown ether–uranyl salophen receptors to be used as stabilizing scaffold for pentavalent uranyl cations. In addition, the possibility of forming coordination polymers through uranyl cation–metal complexation, as in structure R 2 ·NaI, might have potential for utilizing this type of molecular structure in building magnetic materials. This could possibly be achieved through fine-tuning the reaction conditions needed for the reduction of UO2 2+ to UO2 +, and selecting the correct metal for magnetic properties.

Also, a solid-state complex with pentavalent uranium coordinated to crown-ether-complexed potassium cation has been obtained. In this case the crown ether complexation of the potassium cation disrupts the polymer formation. Obtained structures with interaction motif I present the potential for crown ether-uranyl salophen receptors to be used as stabilizing scaffold for pentavalent uranyl cations. In addition, the possibility of forming coordination polymers through uranyl cation-metal complexation, as in structure R  2  ⋅NaI, might have potential for utilizing this type of molecular structure in building magnetic materials. This could possibly be achieved through fine-tuning the reaction conditions needed for the reduction of UO2 2+ to UO2 +, and selecting the correct metal for magnetic properties.

elements.content: All of the sodium-containing ion pair complexes show different behaviors from one another. The structure obtained with NaF can be considered to have interaction motif IIIc (, Figure S15), but it is also considerably different compared to the other structures with interaction motif III. The packing in complex R 2 ·NaF is heavily affected by the large amount of solvate molecules, which form an extensive hydrogen bonding network. Even the two solid-state structures obtained with R 2 and NaBr are very different from one another, and show complicated interplay between the receptors and ion pairs. In structure R 2 ·NaBr_1 there is a dimeric complex of two R 2 receptors, thus defined as having interaction motif Ib, but it also contains a single R 2 molecule complexed with sodium (Figure S16). None of the bromide anions are coordinated in the uranyl centers, and the uranyl centers are coordinated with water or methanol molecules. An extremely complicated structure was found in the solid-state complex R 2 ·NaBr_2 (Figure S17). The structure consists of eight receptor molecules, with two dimeric complexes, two isolated receptors, and two receptor molecules forming a 1D-coordination polymer through ion pair coordination between uranyl-coordinated bromide anion, and the sodium cation residing in the crown ether of the adjacent receptor. All the R 2 molecules are complexed with sodium cations, and six of the uranyl centers are coordinated with water molecules. This structure can be thought to have interaction motifs I and II, with separated and contact ion pairs in the structure. However, the interaction motif II observed in R 2 ·NaBr_2 differs from the other structures due to the complete linearity of the molecules responsible for forming the coordination polymer through contact ion pairs (Figure S17). Given the two different structures obtained with NaBr, and the very complicated nature of the structures, NaBr can be considered as a “confused” ion pair for complexation with R 2 . This might stem from the nature of the bromide anion, and the size of the sodium cation compared to the size of 18-crown-6 ring. In addition, the solid-state complex R 1 ·NaBr () is also deviating from all the other obtained solid-state structures with ion pairs, having the interaction motif IIIb () with contact ion pair, and closely resembling the structures obtained with only receptors and solvent molecules.

The structure consists of eight receptor molecules, with two dimeric complexes, two isolated receptors, and two receptor molecules forming a 1D-coordination polymer through ion pair coordination between uranyl-coordinated bromide anion, and the sodium cation residing in the crown ether of the adjacent receptor. elements.content: X-ray quality crystals of R 2 ·KF were obtained by evaporation of acetonitrile solution of R 2 with 2 equiv of KF added in methanol. The complex crystallized in monoclinic space group P21/n with one molecule of R 2 and 1 equiv of KF in the asymmetric unit. The complex represents interaction motif II, having a contact ion pair between the uranyl-coordinated fluoride anion and the potassium cation complexed in the crown ether of the adjacent receptor ( and Figure S19). The potassium cation resides slightly above the crown ether plane due to the strong coordinative bond to the fluoride anion (2.755 Å), which is coordinated to the uranyl center with distance 2.216 Å. The K+···O­(crown ether) bond lengths are between 2.840 and 3.133 Å, which are noticeably longer than the K+···O­(crown ether) bond lengths in other potassium-containing complexes (for example, in the R 2 ·KCl complex, K+···O distances are 2.708–2.915 Å). The eighth coordination bond of the potassium is formed to the oxygen atom in the salophen scaffold with bond length 2.797 Å. This type of coordination results in 1D-polymeric structure along the crystallographic b-axis.

The structure has interaction motif II, a contact ion pair between uranyl-coordinated fluoride and crown ether complexed potassium cation in the adjacent molecule. The potassium cation is further coordinated to an oxygen atom in the salophen scaffold. This type of packing results in a polymeric structure along the crystallographic b-axis. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. [Unit cell parameters: monoclinic, a = 15.3600(7) Å, b = 16.1948(6) Å, c = 15.6551(7) Å, β = 113.516(2)°.]
elements.clean_text: 5  Solid-state complex R  2  ⋅KF. The structure has interaction motif II, a contact ion pair between uranyl-coordinated fluoride and crown ether complexed potassium cation in the adjacent molecule. The potassium cation is further coordinated to an oxygen atom in the salophen scaffold. This type of packing results in a polymeric structure along the crystallographic b-axis. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. [Unit cell parameters: monoclinic, a = 15.3600(7) Å, b = 16.1948(6) Å, c = 15.6551(7) Å, β = 113.516(2)°.]

elements.content: A similar interaction motif was observed also in complexes R 1 ·RbF (Figure S12), R 1 ·CsF (Figure S13), R 2 ·RbCl (Figure S24), and R 2 ·CsCl (Figure S25), showing a trend between the alkali halide and crown ether size mismatch, and the Lewis basicity of the anion. The interaction motif II observed with R 2 and KF is probably due to the large point charges of the cation and anion, and the strong ion–ion interaction, which is not overcome by the other weak interactions between R 2 and the ions.
elements.clean_text: A similar interaction motif was observed also in complexes R  1  ⋅RbF (Figure S12), R  1  ⋅CsF (Figure S13), R  2  ⋅RbCl (Figure S24), and R  2  ⋅CsCl (Figure S25), showing a trend between the alkali halide and crown ether size mismatch, and the Lewis basicity of the anion. The interaction motif II observed with R  2  and KF is probably due to the large point charges of the cation and anion, and the strong ion-ion interaction, which is not overcome by the other weak interactions between R  2  and the ions.

elements.content: Crystals of R 2 ·NH 4 Br were obtained by slow evaporation of acetonitrile solution of R 2 with NH4Br added in excess in water. The complex crystallized in monoclinic space group P21/n containing one R 2 molecule and 1 equiv of NH4Br in the asymmetric unit. The obtained structure is isostructural to the ones obtained with KF, and larger alkali metal fluorides and chlorides. The ammonium cation is hydrogen bonded with the oxygen atoms of the crown ether with N···O distances 2.869–3.213 Å ( and Figure S26). The fourth hydrogen atom of the ammonium cation is further forming a hydrogen bond with salophen oxygen of the adjacent receptor molecule (2.88 Å), corresponding to the coordinative bond between alkali metal cation and the salophen oxygen in the other solid-state structures with interaction motif II. The bromide anion is coordinated to the uranyl center with bond length 2.895 Å, being the shortest of the observed U···Br– distances. There is a very weak contact between the ammonium cation and bromide, with the distance being 3.462 Å. Nevertheless, being isostructural with R 2 ·KF, this complex can be considered to have interaction motif II, although the ion pair contact is very weak. The obtained structure gives more insight into the dependence of the interaction motif with the cation size, again showing that the large cations favor the formation of contact ion pair complexes with R 1 and R 2 .
elements.clean_text:
R2⋅NH4Br

Crystals of R  2  ⋅NH  4  Br were obtained by slow evaporation of acetonitrile solution of R  2  with NH4Br added in excess in water. The complex crystallized in monoclinic space group P21/n containing one R  2  molecule and 1 equiv of NH4Br in the asymmetric unit. The obtained structure is isostructural to the ones obtained with KF, and larger alkali metal fluorides and chlorides. The ammonium cation is hydrogen bonded with the oxygen atoms of the crown ether with N⋅⋅⋅O distances 2.869-3.213 Å ( and Figure S26). The fourth hydrogen atom of the ammonium cation is further forming a hydrogen bond with salophen oxygen of the adjacent receptor molecule (2.88 Å), corresponding to the coordinative bond between alkali metal cation and the salophen oxygen in the other solid-state structures with interaction motif II. The bromide anion is coordinated to the uranyl center with bond length 2.895 Å, being the shortest of the observed U⋅⋅⋅Br- distances. There is a very weak contact between the ammonium cation and bromide, with the distance being 3.462 Å. Nevertheless, being isostructural with R  2  ⋅KF, this complex can be considered to have interaction motif II, although the ion pair contact is very weak. The obtained structure gives more insight into the dependence of the interaction motif with the cation size, again showing that the large cations favor the formation of contact ion pair complexes with R  1  and R  2 .

The complex is isostructural to R 1 ·RbF, R 1 ·CsF, R 2 ·KF, R 2 ·RbCl, and R 2 ·CsCl. [Unit cell parameters: monoclinic, a = 15.6623(2) Å, b = 16.1742(2) Å, c = 15.9467(2) Å, β = 111.5130(10)°.]

elements.content: Single-crystals of R 1 ·DMSO were grown by slow evaporation of acetone/DMSO solution of R 1 in the presence of CsCl. The structure crystallized in orthorhombic space group Pbcn. The obtained structure represents interaction motif IIIa. The asymmetric unit consists of one molecule of R 1 , with DMSO molecule coordinated to the uranyl center, and two water molecules hydrogen bonded with the crown ether and salophen oxygen atom ( and Figure S9). Two receptor molecules stack on top of each other, via various weak interactions between the receptor molecules, and solvent mediated interactions. For example, the water molecule hydrogen bonded to the crown ether acts also as a weak hydrogen bond acceptor to the iminic hydrogen atom in the adjacent R 1 molecule. The DMSO molecule is coordinated to the uranyl center with bond length 2.380 Å, being slightly shorter than the average U···O distance (2.426 Å). The coordinated DMSO molecule has weak interactions with the uranyl moiety in the adjacent receptor, thus contributing to the packing of the stacked receptor columns. Similar stacking of the receptor molecules is also present in structures R 1 ·H 2 O (space group P21/c, Figure S8) and R 2 ·H 2 O (space group Cc, Figure S14), but the weak interactions responsible for the overall structure differ due to the variable solvate constitution in the structures. Thus, the solvate molecules are heavily affecting the overall packing of the structures, and are responsible to some extent for stacking the receptor molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Interaction Motif III

R1⋅DMSO

Single-crystals of R  1  ⋅DMSO were grown by slow evaporation of acetone/DMSO solution of R  1  in the presence of CsCl. The structure crystallized in orthorhombic space group Pbcn. The obtained structure represents interaction motif IIIa. The asymmetric unit consists of one molecule of R  1 , with DMSO molecule coordinated to the uranyl center, and two water molecules hydrogen bonded with the crown ether and salophen oxygen atom ( and Figure S9). Two receptor molecules stack on top of each other, via various weak interactions between the receptor molecules, and solvent mediated interactions. For example, the water molecule hydrogen bonded to the crown ether acts also as a weak hydrogen bond acceptor to the iminic hydrogen atom in the adjacent R  1  molecule. The DMSO molecule is coordinated to the uranyl center with bond length 2.380 Å, being slightly shorter than the average U⋅⋅⋅O distance (2.426 Å). The coordinated DMSO molecule has weak interactions with the uranyl moiety in the adjacent receptor, thus contributing to the packing of the stacked receptor columns. Similar stacking of the receptor molecules is also present in structures R  1  ⋅H  2  O (space group P21/c, Figure S8) and R  2  ⋅H  2  O (space group Cc, Figure S14), but the weak interactions responsible for the overall structure differ due to the variable solvate constitution in the structures. Thus, the solvate molecules are heavily affecting the overall packing of the structures, and are responsible to some extent for stacking the receptor molecules.

elements.content: Solid-state complex R 1 ·DMSO. The structure represents interaction motif IIIa, with stacked packing of the receptor molecules. DMSO molecule is coordinated to the uranyl center, and water molecules are hydrogen bonded with the crown ether oxygens, and salophen oxygen atom. [Unit cell parameters: orthorhombic, a = 26.8748(7) Å, b = 7.85585(16) Å, c = 31.2173(7) Å.]

elements.content: Single-crystals of R 1 ·NaBr were obtained by slow diffusion of diethyl ether into methanol solution of R 1 with NaBr added in excess in water. The complex crystallized in monoclinic space group P21/n, with two R 1 molecules and 2 equiv of NaBr in the asymmetric unit ( and Figure S11). Interestingly, the R 1 ·NaBr complexes stack similarly to the R 1 and R 2 molecules without ion pairs present in the structure, representing interaction motif IIIb. Sodium bromide forms contact ion pairs with distances 2.761 and 2.808 Å. The bromide anions are interacting with the iminic protons in the adjacent receptor molecules through weak hydrogen bonds, as seen also in structure R 1 ·DMSO. In addition, there is a weak C–H···Br– hydrogen bond with aromatic proton of the salophen moiety. The uranyl centers are coordinated with methanol and water molecules with bond lengths of 2.416 and 2.43 Å, respectively. The methanol forms hydrogen bonds to the uranyl oxygen in the adjacent complex, thus contributing to the packing of the stacked complexes.
elements.clean_text:
R1⋅NaBr

Single-crystals of R  1  ⋅NaBr were obtained by slow diffusion of diethyl ether into methanol solution of R  1  with NaBr added in excess in water. The complex crystallized in monoclinic space group P21/n, with two R  1  molecules and 2 equiv of NaBr in the asymmetric unit ( and Figure S11). Interestingly, the R  1  ⋅NaBr complexes stack similarly to the R  1  and R  2  molecules without ion pairs present in the structure, representing interaction motif IIIb. Sodium bromide forms contact ion pairs with distances 2.761 and 2.808 Å. The bromide anions are interacting with the iminic protons in the adjacent receptor molecules through weak hydrogen bonds, as seen also in structure R  1  ⋅DMSO. In addition, there is a weak C-H⋅⋅⋅Br- hydrogen bond with aromatic proton of the salophen moiety. The uranyl centers are coordinated with methanol and water molecules with bond lengths of 2.416 and 2.43 Å, respectively. The methanol forms hydrogen bonds to the uranyl oxygen in the adjacent complex, thus contributing to the packing of the stacked complexes.

elements.content:
We have presented the synthesis of two ditopic crown ether uranyl salophen receptors either with 15-crown-5 (R 1 ) or 18-crown-6 units (R 2 ), for ion pair complexation in the solid-state.

The in-depth solid-state studies have revealed three distinctive interaction receptor motifs. Interaction motif I is defined as having a separated ion pair in the structure, with interaction motif II defined as having a contact ion pair; interaction motif III is defined as stacked packing of the receptors (with or without ion pairs). In the presence of fluoride or chloride they are coordinated to the uranium due to their strong Lewis basicity. In the obtained structures with bromide salts, the bromide anion, being a weaker Lewis base, is labile in its coordination behavior toward the uranyl center, with only a few of the structures having uranyl–bromide coordination. In the two iodide structures, obtained with NaI and KI, the anion is not coordinated to the uranyl center due to the very low Lewis basicity and large size of the iodide, and act merely as weak hydrogen bond acceptors within the crystal lattice. In the course of this work also the first uranyl salophen complex with uranyl-coordinated acetate anion was obtained. The observed uranium to acatate oxygen atom bond distance is slightly longer than expected from the other U···O– complexes. This might be due to the hydrogen bonding of the acetate anion with methanol solvate molecules, thus weakening the coordinative bond between uranium and oxygen. This type of phenomenon was observed also with other anions or solvent molecules hydrogen bonded with solvate molecules. The crown ether complexed cation has an important effect on the interaction motif of the complex, being responsible for dimerization of the receptors (interaction motif I) or formation of contact ion pairs, and consecutive formation of 1D-coordination polymers (interaction motif II). The solid-state complex R 2 ·NaI has a distinctive structure with [O···Na+···OUO] units forming coordination polymers throughout the structures. The recent examples of stabilization of pentavalent uranyl with salen or salophen scaffolds, and the utilization of these structures in magnetic applications, give intriguing ideas about using these crown ether uranyl salophen molecules for similar purposes.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

We have presented the synthesis of two ditopic crown ether uranyl salophen receptors either with 15-crown-5 (R  1 ) or 18-crown-6 units (R  2 ), for ion pair complexation in the solid-state.

The in-depth solid-state studies have revealed three distinctive interaction receptor motifs. Interaction motif I is defined as having a separated ion pair in the structure, with interaction motif II defined as having a contact ion pair; interaction motif III is defined as stacked packing of the receptors (with or without ion pairs). In the presence of fluoride or chloride they are coordinated to the uranium due to their strong Lewis basicity. In the obtained structures with bromide salts, the bromide anion, being a weaker Lewis base, is labile in its coordination behavior toward the uranyl center, with only a few of the structures having uranyl-bromide coordination. In the two iodide structures, obtained with NaI and KI, the anion is not coordinated to the uranyl center due to the very low Lewis basicity and large size of the iodide, and act merely as weak hydrogen bond acceptors within the crystal lattice. In the course of this work also the first uranyl salophen complex with uranyl-coordinated acetate anion was obtained. The observed uranium to acatate oxygen atom bond distance is slightly longer than expected from the other U⋅⋅⋅O- complexes. This might be due to the hydrogen bonding of the acetate anion with methanol solvate molecules, thus weakening the coordinative bond between uranium and oxygen. This type of phenomenon was observed also with other anions or solvent molecules hydrogen bonded with solvate molecules. The crown ether complexed cation has an important effect on the interaction motif of the complex, being responsible for dimerization of the receptors (interaction motif I) or formation of contact ion pairs, and consecutive formation of 1D-coordination polymers (interaction motif II). The solid-state complex R  2  ⋅NaI has a distinctive structure with [O⋅⋅⋅Na+⋅⋅⋅OUO] units forming coordination polymers throughout the structures. The recent examples of stabilization of pentavalent uranyl with salen or salophen scaffolds, and the utilization of these structures in magnetic applications, give intriguing ideas about using these crown ether uranyl salophen molecules for similar purposes.

cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Synthesis of Receptors R  1  and R  2

cln_elements.content: General interaction motifs observed in the solid-state structures of R 1 and R 2 : I, separated ion pair; II, contact ion pair; IIIa, stacked packing of the receptors with solvent molecules; IIIb, stacked packing with contact ion pair (R 1 ·NaBr); IIIc, stacked packing with separated ion pair (R 2 ·NaF). The general schemes are presented only for R 2 although similar interaction motifs are observed also with R 1 . M+ = alkali or ammonium cation, X– = halide or acetate anion, Sol = solvent molecule.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  General interaction motifs observed in the solid-state structures of R  1  and R  2 : I, separated ion pair; II, contact ion pair; IIIa, stacked packing of the receptors with solvent molecules; IIIb, stacked packing with contact ion pair (R  1 ⋅NaBr); IIIc, stacked packing with separated ion pair (R  2 ⋅NaF). The general schemes are presented only for R  2  although similar interaction motifs are observed also with R  1 . M+ = alkali or ammonium cation, X- = halide or acetate anion, Sol = solvent molecule.

cln_elements.content: Solid-state complex R 1 ·LiCl. The complex has interaction motif Ia with two receptor molecules forming a dimer through Li···OUO coordination. The chloride anion is coordinated in the fifth equatorial coordination site of the uranyl center, further hydrogen bonded with two water molecules. Only selected hydrogen atoms are shown. [Unit cell parameters: monoclinic, a = 16.9290(3) Å, b = 18.4658(3) Å, c = 23.7388(5) Å, β = 101.620(2)°.]
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Solid-state complex R  1  ⋅LiCl. The complex has interaction motif Ia with two receptor molecules forming a dimer through Li⋅⋅⋅OUO coordination. The chloride anion is coordinated in the fifth equatorial coordination site of the uranyl center, further hydrogen bonded with two water molecules. Only selected hydrogen atoms are shown. [Unit cell parameters: monoclinic, a = 16.9290(3) Å, b = 18.4658(3) Å, c = 23.7388(5) Å, β = 101.620(2)°.]

cln_elements.content: Solid-state complex R 2 ·KAcO. (a) Dimeric assembly forms via K+···OUO coordination, and the acetate anion is coordinated to the uranyl center with bond length 2.356 Å. Acetate anion is further hydrogen bonded with methanol solvate molecules. (b) Dimers further coordinate to the potassium cations in the adjacent dimers, resulting in 1D coordination polymer along the crystallographic a-axis. Only selected hydrogen atoms are shown. [Unit cell parameters: monoclinic, a = 12.0489(2) Å, b = 18.5382(3) Å, c = 16.2273(3) Å, β = 94.060(1)°.]
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Solid-state complex R  2  ⋅KAcO. (a) Dimeric assembly forms via K+⋅⋅⋅OUO coordination, and the acetate anion is coordinated to the uranyl center with bond length 2.356 Å. Acetate anion is further hydrogen bonded with methanol solvate molecules. (b) Dimers further coordinate to the potassium cations in the adjacent dimers, resulting in 1D coordination polymer along the crystallographic a-axis. Only selected hydrogen atoms are shown. [Unit cell parameters: monoclinic, a = 12.0489(2) Å, b = 18.5382(3) Å, c = 16.2273(3) Å, β = 94.060(1)°.]

cln_elements.content: Solid-state complex R 2 ·NaI. (a) Structure consists of stacks of receptor molecules forming infinite coordination polymers along the a-axis. The uranyl center is coordinated by water molecule. Iodide anions are omitted from the picture for clarity. (b) Repeating O···Na+···OUO units shown in more detail. The total length of the repeating unit is 8.203 Å. Only selected hydrogen atoms are shown. [Unit cell parameters: monoclinic, a = 8.2027(2) Å, b = 18.5028(5) Å, c = 22.9036(5) Å, β = 93.010(1)°.]
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  Solid-state complex R  2  ⋅NaI. (a) Structure consists of stacks of receptor molecules forming infinite coordination polymers along the a-axis. The uranyl center is coordinated by water molecule. Iodide anions are omitted from the picture for clarity. (b) Repeating O⋅⋅⋅Na+⋅⋅⋅OUO units shown in more detail. The total length of the repeating unit is 8.203 Å. Only selected hydrogen atoms are shown. [Unit cell parameters: monoclinic, a = 8.2027(2) Å, b = 18.5028(5) Å, c = 22.9036(5) Å, β = 93.010(1)°.]

cln_elements.content: Solid-state complex R 2 ·KF. The structure has interaction motif II, a contact ion pair between uranyl-coordinated fluoride and crown ether complexed potassium cation in the adjacent molecule. The potassium cation is further coordinated to an oxygen atom in the salophen scaffold. This type of packing results in a polymeric structure along the crystallographic b-axis. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. [Unit cell parameters: monoclinic, a = 15.3600(7) Å, b = 16.1948(6) Å, c = 15.6551(7) Å, β = 113.516(2)°.]
cln_elements.clean_text: 5  Solid-state complex R  2  ⋅KF. The structure has interaction motif II, a contact ion pair between uranyl-coordinated fluoride and crown ether complexed potassium cation in the adjacent molecule. The potassium cation is further coordinated to an oxygen atom in the salophen scaffold. This type of packing results in a polymeric structure along the crystallographic b-axis. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. [Unit cell parameters: monoclinic, a = 15.3600(7) Å, b = 16.1948(6) Å, c = 15.6551(7) Å, β = 113.516(2)°.]

cln_elements.content: Solid-state complex R 2 ·NH 4 Br. The structure can be considered to have interaction motif II although the ion pair contact is very weak. The complex is isostructural to R 1 ·RbF, R 1 ·CsF, R 2 ·KF, R 2 ·RbCl, and R 2 ·CsCl. [Unit cell parameters: monoclinic, a = 15.6623(2) Å, b = 16.1742(2) Å, c = 15.9467(2) Å, β = 111.5130(10)°.]
cln_elements.clean_text: 6  Solid-state complex R  2  ⋅NH  4  Br. The structure can be considered to have interaction motif II although the ion pair contact is very weak. The complex is isostructural to R  1  ⋅RbF, R  1  ⋅CsF, R  2  ⋅KF, R  2  ⋅RbCl, and R  2  ⋅CsCl. [Unit cell parameters: monoclinic, a = 15.6623(2) Å, b = 16.1742(2) Å, c = 15.9467(2) Å, β = 111.5130(10)°.]

cln_elements.content: Solid-state complex R 1 ·DMSO. The structure represents interaction motif IIIa, with stacked packing of the receptor molecules. DMSO molecule is coordinated to the uranyl center, and water molecules are hydrogen bonded with the crown ether oxygens, and salophen oxygen atom. [Unit cell parameters: orthorhombic, a = 26.8748(7) Å, b = 7.85585(16) Å, c = 31.2173(7) Å.]
cln_elements.clean_text: 7  Solid-state complex R  1  ⋅DMSO. The structure represents interaction motif IIIa, with stacked packing of the receptor molecules. DMSO molecule is coordinated to the uranyl center, and water molecules are hydrogen bonded with the crown ether oxygens, and salophen oxygen atom. [Unit cell parameters: orthorhombic, a = 26.8748(7) Å, b = 7.85585(16) Å, c = 31.2173(7) Å.]

cln_elements.content: Solid-state complex R 1 ·NaBr. The complex has interaction motif III despite the contact ion pairs in the structure. Uranyl centers are coordinated with water and methanol molecules. [Unit cell parameters: monoclinic, a = 8.02121(18) Å, b = 32.1044(11) Å, c = 25.8906(6) Å, β = 97.497(2)°.]
cln_elements.clean_text: 8  Solid-state complex R  1  ⋅NaBr. The complex has interaction motif III despite the contact ion pairs in the structure. Uranyl centers are coordinated with water and methanol molecules. [Unit cell parameters: monoclinic, a = 8.02121(18) Å, b = 32.1044(11) Å, c = 25.8906(6) Å, β = 97.497(2)°.]
